Replacing this component restored carriage movement. However, the carriage would move only slightly before returning to its starting position.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5523): Adjustment of Platter and Sub-Chassis Alignment, Installation of New Transport Lock Bushings and Adjustment of the Tonearm
item.description: After restoring the mechanics and electronics of a Beogram 4002 (5523) turntable, it was time to ensure proper alignment of the platter, sub-chassis, and tonearm. The first step was centering the sub-chassis within the transport locks. However, a previous repair attempt had misaligned the transport locks, preventing adjustment. Taking the opportunity, new bushings were installed to replace the deteriorated originals, evidenced by orange plastic fragments within the enclosure. [Images of deteriorated bushings and new bushings installed]

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Re-Attaching Keypad Segments
item.description: My Beogram 4002 (5513) restoration is moving along, and I’m currently focusing on aesthetics. The last step was to reattach two keypad sections that had become unglued. The image illustrates the problem: I used a small amount of superglue gel and clamped the pads down with vise grips: It’s important to use minimal glue to avoid damaging the delicate paint on the pad’s surface. Start with a small amount and add more if needed.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5501): Replacing all Electrolytic Capacitors
item.description: Following the repair of a peculiar control system problem, I proceeded with the comprehensive restoration process. This involved replacing all electrolytic capacitors, a crucial step given their tendency to dry out in these units. Notably, Ta type capacitors can become a fire hazard upon failure, making the upgrade to modern Aluminum 105C types a wise decision. The main PCB in its original state is depicted here: And here it is after capacitor replacement:

item.title: Beogram 4000: Rebuilding the Arm Lowering and Tracking Systems
item.description: Following the repair of the MMC cartridge mount on the Beogram 4000, attention shifted to the malfunctioning arm lowering and tracking mechanisms. The arm lowering system, comprising a solenoid and damper, was examined. The damper and its associated linkages were removed for cleaning and lubrication. Inspection revealed the absence of a vital rubber washer in the damper unit, substituted with a makeshift transparency foil piece. This modification hindered proper damper function.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Gold Plating of Carriage Position Switch Terminals
item.description: Following the restoration of the Beogram 4000’s control panel (keypad), the next step was to focus on the carriage position switches. These switches are vital for the Beogram 4000’s digital control system, and even one faulty switch can render the entire device unusable. Similar to the keypad switches, these are prone to oxidation, making gold plating a reliable solution to prevent future contact problems. The image below displays the circuit board with the switches after detaching the carriage position indicator component.

item.title: Beogram 4000: A New Arrival from California with a Bit of Shipping Damage
item.description: A Beogram 4000 turntable arrived needing some care, but unfortunately experienced additional damage during shipping. Upon opening the box, it was discovered that the carriage had detached from the pulley, which was stuck to tape residue. Thankfully, the tonearm was secured with tape, preventing it from ejecting through the platter opening and causing more severe damage. However, the tonearm did sustain some impact. This highlights the importance of securing the carriage during transport using foam and tape.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): First Contact and Test Drive
item.description: I recently acquired a Beogram 4002 (5513) turntable in good condition that needed some attention. I connected it to my Beosystem 6000 to test it, but a loud hum started immediately when I turned on the Beomaster 6000. Upon closer inspection, I discovered that P9 on the printed circuit board was installed backward. This connector isn’t polarized, so it can be inserted either way. Fortunately, this doesn’t cause damage because the connector doesn’t carry any power.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5503): Unit Switches Immediately to 45 RPM After Pressing Start
item.description: The Beogram 4002 (5503) turntable being restored exhibited a peculiar issue during initial testing. Upon starting, the tonearm moved as expected but the speed immediately switched to 45 RPM. Pressing the 33 RPM button temporarily resolved the issue, but the speed reverted back upon release. This unusual behavior pointed to a potential problem with transistors TR3 or TR2. Examining the circuit diagram, we can see how speed selection operates: The speed control mechanism utilizes a flip-flop circuit with transistors TR3 and TR4.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Restoration of DC Platter Motor and Main PCB
item.description: I recently obtained a main PCB and DC platter motor from a Beogram 4002. I began with the motor refurbishment, a process that often requires several days for the bearings to become saturated with oil. The motor is depicted here: Disassembly was necessary to access the bearings, visible as two small rings on the black component in the front: The motor’s interior was noticeably oily, suggesting prior tampering. This was supported by a damaged commutator brush that was bent out of its intended form:

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5523): Some Final Touches - Replacing Plinth and Keypad
item.description: Following the installation of the BeoloverRIAA internal preamplifier and the Commander remote control, this Beogram 4002 (5523) needed a few finishing touches. The original plinth of the Beogram was damaged. A replacement plinth was sourced, but it also had minor damage, particularly to the corners. Inspired by a previous veneer repair on a Beomaster 8000, a similar approach was taken to address the plinth’s corners. Veneer was added and color-matched to the existing finish, significantly improving the appearance, although not completely perfect.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (Type 5513): A New Arrival from Florida - First Assessment
item.description: A local customer brought me a Beogram 4002 (5513) for restoration last year, opting for the safety of personal delivery. The unit is in decent condition, as seen upon arrival. [Image] The dust cover is nearly flawless, with one common hinge crack just starting to form. [Image] This makes it a perfect candidate for Beolover hinge patches to reinforce the area, especially since the crack hasn’t fully developed. Of course, new hoods are an option now as well.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Replacing the Reservoir and Motor Electrolytic Capacitors
item.description: Following the gold plating of all switch terminals on a Beogram 4000 restoration project, the next step involved addressing the electronics. The restoration typically begins by replacing outdated reservoir and motor capacitors, as they are frequently out of specification and nearing failure. The image provided showcases these original components. To ensure proper fitment of the (smaller) modern replacement capacitors, a custom 3D-printed fixture was designed and utilized. This fixture secures the capacitors in the correct position.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5514): Replacing all Electrolytic Capacitors and Rebuilding of the Platter RPM Control System
item.description: During the electronic restoration of a Beogram 4002 (5514) turntable, the electrolytic capacitors were replaced and new relays were installed to enhance RPM stability. The aging tantalum capacitors, known for their tendency to fail catastrophically, were replaced as a precautionary measure. The main board was refurbished, replacing the electrolytic capacitors and installing new relays, including a custom-designed replacement for the Siemens relay that ensures precise RPM control. The original reservoir capacitor, a dual-capacitor unit no longer in production, was replaced with a 3D-printed fixture housing two modern capacitors.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5521): A Stuck Tonearm and Polishing the Hood
item.description: A Beogram 4002 turntable, which I had previously repaired, returned with a tonearm tracking issue. The problem was a misaligned tracking sensor aperture obstructing the arm’s movement. To fix this, I slightly repositioned the aperture after loosening its screw. I replaced the original screw with a more secure flat socket head screw to prevent future misalignment. I then recalibrated the tracking sensor feedback. While the Beogram was with me, the customer decided to have the dust cover polished.

item.title: Beogram 4002 Type 5501 from Sweden: Full Technical Restoration and Some Interesting Issues
item.description: I recently acquired a Beogram 4002 turntable (Type 5501 with optical carriage position detection) for a complete technical restoration. The unit arrived without a dust cover. Here’s a picture of the Beogram right after unpacking: Besides a number of loose parts that fell out when I opened the box, I was surprised to see that the cartridge was still mounted on the tonearm: Fortunately, the MMC4000 cartridge had a small plexiglass guard in place, preventing any damage.

item.title: Beogram 4002 Type 5513: Results of Initial Platter Motor Test
item.description: I ran the Beogram for slightly more than a day and then analyzed the logged measurement data. As shown in the graph, which plots RPM over time, the turntable speed remained relatively stable at the target 33 1/3 RPM, but there were noticeable drops, reaching as low as 30.324 RPM after about three and a half hours. This result aligns with Beolover’s initial findings when testing similar motors. Based on other Beogram DC motor tests conducted by Beolover, it will be revealing to observe the performance of this Beogram after re-lubricating the platter motor bearings.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Replacement of the Sensor Arm Bulb with an LED and Improvement of the Record Detection Circuit
item.description: Replacing the sensor arm LED is typically the final step in converting a Beogram 4002 to use all LEDs. After restoring the DC motor, the next task was to install a recently designed flex-PCB-based LED assembly to replace the incandescent bulb. The image below shows the sensor arm with the detector assembly removed: Upon zooming in on the full-resolution image, a small black spot is visible on the glass bulb. This spot indicates significant tungsten evaporation from the filament, suggesting the bulb is nearing the end of its life and could soon fail, rendering the Beogram inoperable.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Restoration of DC Motor: A New Tool and a New Spark Suppressor
item.description: I worked on restoring a Beogram 4002 DC motor, a process that unveiled a new and interesting failure point for these motors. This experience further refines the restoration process for these motors. The motor needed its usual oil infusion for the porous brass bearings. The motor’s rough operation when powered confirmed this need. Upon disassembly, I found this motor had the older brush carrier design, notorious for being glued to the alignment posts and feedback coils.

item.title: Beogram 4002: Restoration of DC Platter Motor
item.description: I obtained a Beogram 4002 DC platter motor from the Netherlands, but couldn’t use it. The top bearing suspension was damaged beyond repair. As a result, I refurbished a different motor I had on hand. To lubricate the bearings, I took the motor apart and submerged them in oil. A vacuum was applied to the oil-submerged bearings. This caused significant bubbling, signifying air escaping from the bearing material and creating space for oil to enter.

item.title: Beogram 4002 Type 5513: RPM Trimmer Panel
item.description: In addition to working on the tangential arm assembly, the RPM trimmer panel was also restored. Testing by Beolover has demonstrated that this upgrade reduces the heat affecting the platter motor control circuit and improves the motor’s stability. The original trimmer assembly is shown here with its two original lamps. The Beolover replacement LED lamp assemblies are designed to be connected to the same solder pads as the original lamps, eliminating the need for board modifications.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Replacing the DIN 5 Cable with a Cable Featuring RCA Plugs
item.description: I am rebuilding a Beogram 4002(5513) turntable to use with a McIntosh Preamplifier. The standard DIN5 connector on Bang & Olufsen equipment is incompatible, so I am replacing it with RCA connectors for the best shielding and lowest EMI. Direct installation inside the turntable offers superior performance compared to adapters. For optimal sound, I chose high-quality, open-ended RCA cables from Sounds Heavenly in the UK. These cables feature individually shielded, twisted-pair left and right channels, embodying an “audiophile” design.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5523): Rebuilding the Control System and RPM Stability Qualification with the BeoloverRPM Device
item.description: After addressing the fundamental components, such as the tracking system and platter motor, in the Beogram 4002 (5523) restoration project, I turned my attention to enhancing the electronic control system. This involved replacing electrolytic capacitors, baseline RPM trimmers, and the RPM and output relays. Additionally, I incorporated a grounding switch to connect system and signal grounds, a measure often effective in mitigating ground loop/humming problems. Here are some noteworthy observations:

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5503): Adjustment of Sub-Chassis, Platter and Tonearm Weight and Limits
item.description: The final stage of restoring the Beogram 4002 (5503) involved balancing the sub-chassis, setting the correct platter height, and adjusting the tonearm. To ensure the best range of motion, the sub-chassis must be carefully positioned between the transport lock clamps. The platter height and vertical alignment need to be set so that the platter sits level with the Beogram’s aluminum covers. This allows for the arm’s lowering limit to be established and the tracking weight to be calibrated against the adjustment dial located on the arm weight housing.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Complete Functional Restoration and Installation of a Beolover Commander Remote Control
item.description: This article details the comprehensive restoration of a Beogram 4002 (5513) turntable. The initial evaluation of this unit is detailed in a separate post. The turntable was first disassembled, revealing the need for bearing lubrication in the platter motor, a common issue in these models. This process typically takes a few days. While the bearings were being re-lubricated, the intricate carriage mechanism, responsible for raising and lowering the tonearm, was addressed.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Restoration of the Keypad Assembly - Gold Plated Switch Terminals and Light Bulbs Replaced with LEDs
item.description: Following the repair of the arm’s lowering and tracking systems, the next step was to focus on the Beogram 4000’s control center: the keypad assembly. This unit houses an early digital control system that manages inputs from the keypad’s keys. The mechanical switches connected to these keys are a common source of problems and should be gold-plated to ensure reliable, long-term operation after restoration. The keypad cluster was removed from the Beogram and opened, revealing a missing light bulb in the position indicator scale.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (Type 5513): Full Functional Restoration and a Test Spin with Stanley Turrentine and Milt Jackson
item.description: This article details the restoration of a Beogram 4002 turntable from Kentucky. The unit, pictured below, was in excellent condition, making it ideal for a complete refurbishment. As is typical with DC motor Beograms, the platter motor was the starting point. These motors commonly suffer from dried-out bearings, leading to speed instability. The extracted motor is shown here: The motor was disassembled to access the bearings: The bearings, visible as two small rings on the black pad, were then submerged in motor oil under a vacuum:

item.title: Beogram 4000: Adjusting the Platter, Floating Chassis, Arm Lowering Limits and Tracking Weight
item.description: The next steps were to make adjustments to the platter, sub-chassis, arm lowering limits, and tracking weight. Additional information on this process is available on my Beogram 4000 page, which includes posts and videos. Before starting, I needed to replace the cabinet guiding washers because they were either damaged or replaced with unsuitable substitutes. [Image of a missing cabinet guidance washer] A video demonstrating this process is available in my Beogram 4002 playlist on my YouTube channel.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (Type 5513): Complete Functional Restoration and a Spin with the Cal Tjader Quartet!
item.description: This article details the restoration of a Beogram 4002 (5513) turntable. The restoration began with addressing the motor, a common procedure for these models. After removing and disassembling the motor, the Oilite bearings were submerged in oil and placed under a vacuum for several days to replenish lubrication. Next, the carriage and arm mechanisms were disassembled, cleaned, and re-lubricated. This included taking apart and servicing the damper. The main PCB was removed, and both power transistors were replaced.

item.title: Beogram 4002 Type 5513: Service Manual Adjustments
item.description: The replacement platter motor from Beolover has arrived, and I’ll be putting it through its paces soon. Meanwhile, I’ve nearly finished the service manual adjustments on this Beogram turntable. The most time-consuming adjustments on these turntables involve the platter height and leveling. This particular Beogram wasn’t level, and the platter height, measured from the top of the fixed arm, was less than the specified 23mm. To fine-tune these, the platters are removed, and the central threaded bearing is adjusted vertically as needed.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Repair of Bent System Ground Terminal
item.description: Following the installation of my newly designed BeoloverRIAA pre-amplifier into a recently restored Beogram 4002, I prepared to reassemble the casing. As I was about to secure the hood, I discovered the system ground terminal on the rear panel was severely bent and damaged. The damage to the threads from rust and deformation prevented the nut’s removal. I was forced to cut the bolt off. Once removed, I replaced it with a new 3mm bolt and used appropriate insulating shoulder washers.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Rebuilding DC Motor with Oil Infused Oilite Bearings
item.description: Following the replacement of the RPM relay and trimmers in the Beogram 4002 (5513) with updated parts, the DC motor required attention. The DC motor often proves to be the most challenging aspect of restoring a 4002 and nearly always demands attention. The primary hurdle lies in restoring the motor’s Oilite oil-infused brass sleeve bearings. These bearings are “pre-lubricated” in a new motor. From a typical consumer perspective, with a lifespan of 10-15 years, these bearings might be considered “maintenance-free.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Gold Coating of Solenoid Activated Switch Terminals
item.description: The Beogram 4000 has a set of four switches, activated by the solenoid, which control its operation when the tonearm is lowered. These switches, like others in the keypad and under the carriage, are prone to oxidation and can cause malfunctions. One crucial switch manages the solenoid current as the tonearm lowers, and if oxidized, it prevents the arm from lowering. It’s highly recommended to have these switches gold-plated for optimal performance.

item.title: Beogram 4002 DC Motor Restoration: Comparison of the RPM Stability Between Four Motors
item.description: Sonavor is currently restoring four Beogram 4002 turntables and recently asked for assistance in refurbishing the DC motors. The restoration process involves removing the motor bearings, cleaning them, and applying fresh oil. To ensure effectiveness, a vacuum is used to draw the oil into the porous bearing material. The bearings are then cleaned of excess oil and reinstalled. After reassembly, each motor undergoes a 24-hour RPM stability test using a specialized device.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): A New Arrival from Tennessee
item.description: A Beogram 4002 (Type 5513) turntable arrived from a Tennessee customer for a complete restoration. The turntable was shipped safely in a Beolover container. This post focuses on the turntable’s initial condition upon arrival. The first photo shows the turntable as it was unpacked. The dust cover has numerous scratches and a spot that appears to be chemical damage. Replacing the existing cover with a new one from Beoparts-shop in Denmark is recommended, along with a new reproduction of the aluminum strip.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Restoration of AC Motor
item.description: I noticed a knocking sound coming from my Beogram 4000’s AC motor, which meant the Oilite brass bearing needed lubrication. These bearings are designed to release oil onto the motor shaft over time. Eventually, they need to be replaced or re-lubricated. Using a food vacuum sealer and a mason jar, you can replenish the oil. Here’s how I did it: First, I removed the motor. Next, I removed the two rivets holding the motor together.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5503): Replacing the Incandescent Light Bulbs in the RPM Indicators with SMD LED Boards
item.description: The Beogram 4002s model 550x has a unique characteristic: the 33 RPM scale light faintly glows when plugged in, even without pressing start. This is because the 550x models use a different method for switching platter speeds compared to earlier models. Unlike the Beogram 4000 and later DC motor models that use a relay, the 550x utilizes electronic RPM switching, evident by the lack of a relay click when changing speeds.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Restoration of PCBs and Reservoir Capacitors
item.description: Following the refurbishment of the tonearm and drive carriage mechanisms on this Beogram 4002 (5513), attention turned to the electronics. The initial phase involved replacing all electrolytic capacitors, RPM trimmers, and the relay to guarantee smooth operation for years to come. The main PCB in its original state is shown here. The same PCB is pictured here after component replacement. This image provides a detailed view of the RPM control section.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5514): Rebuilding a Noisy DC Motor with Oil Infused Bearings
item.description: The majority of Beogram 4002 turntables equipped with a DC motor require motor refurbishment. Indicators of this need include abrupt drops in revolutions per minute (RPM) or audible motor noise during operation. This specific Beogram 4002 (5514) exhibited significant noise during unloaded operation. As part of my restoration process for all 4002 turntables, I comprehensively rebuild the DC motors to preemptively address these common issues. The primary contributor to these performance issues lies in the brass sleeve bearings.

item.title: Beogram 4002 551x: Exciting!! Replica DC Motor Bearing Prototypes from Beoparts Successfully Tested
item.description: I received another set of Beogram 4002 platter motor components and an RPM panel from a customer in the Netherlands to restore. My work started with the motor, as it usually does. I disassembled the motor to get to the bearings. Typically, I would show a picture of the bearings being oiled in a vacuum chamber, but I received new Oilite bearings from www.beoparts-shop.com specifically for these DC motors, which I am testing.

item.title: Beogram 4002: Restoration of DC Motor - Oil Infusion of the Bearings and Installation of New Spark Snubbers
item.description: A Beogram 4002 DC motor arrived from New Zealand for restoration. The upside-down pulley suggested prior repairs. Disassembly revealed a bent brush, a possible cause for the motor’s poor performance. [Image of motor with bent brush] The motor was fully disassembled, and the bearings underwent an oil infusion process to address potential RPM instability, a common issue. [Image of disassembled motor] [Image of bearings in oil] After the infusion, the bent brush was straightened.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Restoration of the DC Motor - Oil Infusion of the Oilite Bearings
item.description: During the restoration of a Beogram 4002 (5513) turntable, the DC motor required attention. The bearings were making noise, indicating a need for lubrication. This is a common issue in Beogram DC motors of this age, often requiring oil replenishment for stable performance. The motor was removed from the turntable for servicing. The bearings, identified as two ring-shaped components, were taken out of the motor. To lubricate them, the bearings were submerged in motor oil, and a vacuum was applied to remove trapped air.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): DC Motor Restoration
item.description: I recently restored a DC motor from a Beogram 4002 (5513) turntable. The turntable exhibited the common issue of inconsistent RPM, indicating the need to lubricate the motor bearings. I documented this process in detail in a video posted earlier. Here are some observations from the motor restoration. The first image shows the motor in its initial condition upon arrival: This image shows the motor after disassembly: The two small “donut” shapes in the front right of the photo are the bearings.

item.title: Beogram 4002 DC Motor Restoration: Oil Infusion of Bearings, Replacement of Spark Snubbers, and Repair of a Disconnected Pickup Coil
item.description: A Beogram 4002 DC motor arrived from Michigan. Initial inspection showed no obvious external issues. However, a bench test revealed the rotor was blocked, preventing the motor from spinning. Upon disassembly, it was evident that someone had previously attempted a repair: the brushes were deformed and a pickup coil pin was broken. Further disassembly revealed a loose and disconnected coil near the missing pin. To address potential bearing issues, the bearings were submerged in motor oil and a vacuum was applied.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Replacing the Incandescent Light Bulbs in the RPM Indicators with LEDs
item.description: During the ongoing restoration of a Beogram 4002 (5513) turntable, the incandescent bulbs illuminating the RPM trimmer scales were replaced with LEDs for enhanced longevity. Custom-designed circuit boards housing SMD LEDs were crafted to seamlessly replace the original bulbs, ensuring a direct fit. These LED assemblies are offered to fellow enthusiasts, with an instructional video demonstrating their installation available online. The following images detail the RPM trimmer panel, initially showcasing the rear view with original bulbs in place.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Rebuilding the Arm Lowering Mechanism and Linear Tracking System
item.description: My restoration project of a Beogram 4002 (5513) turntable started with the arm lowering and tracking mechanisms. These mechanisms often require attention because of hardened lubricants and misadjusted tracking sensors. After taking the mechanism apart for cleaning and lubrication, I addressed the linkage connecting the damper to the tonearm, which commonly experiences stiffness due to hardened lubricants. The sensor arm was then removed for disassembly to further work on the linkage.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): A Broken Off Solenoid Plunger and New Transport Lock Bushings
item.description: A Beogram 4002 turntable, recently serviced and returned to a customer, unexpectedly came back with a faulty tonearm. The culprit was a broken solenoid plunger, a part responsible for lowering the tonearm. This unusual breakage was likely due to material fatigue. To fix the issue, the solenoid was replaced with one from a donor Beogram 4002. During the repair, it was discovered that the transport lock bushings had also deteriorated and needed replacement.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5524): A New Arrival from Texas - A Wrong Hood and Some Blown Fuses
item.description: I recently acquired a Beogram 4002 (Type 5524) turntable from Texas. This particular model features a universal voltage DC motor and a power switch located beneath the unit. The turntable arrived securely packaged in a specialized container, ensuring it was free from any shipping damage. Here’s a photo of the turntable as I received it: B&O enthusiasts might immediately notice something peculiar about this image. The hood’s color seems to suggest it belongs to a Beogram 4000, not a 4002.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5501): Sensor Arm Light Bulb Replacement - Final Version
item.description: This post follows up on my previous writing about replacing incandescent sensor arm bulbs in Beogram 4002 turntables with LEDs. I’ve found that the LED PCB is best positioned 2.5 mm deep in the sensor compartment’s bulb cavity. This maximizes sensor response, likely because light bulb filaments sit slightly lower than the bulb’s rim. For a consistent solution, I designed a 3D-printed wedge that affixes to the flexPCB with epoxy and positions the LED at the optimal depth.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5503): New Cabinet Guiding Washers and Transport Lock Bushings
item.description: To finalize the mechanical repairs on this Beogram 4002 (5503) turntable, new transport lock bushings were necessary. These bushings ensure the sub-chassis is properly aligned within the upper and lower lock positions. This particular Beogram was missing these bushings, with no indication they were ever there. This photo shows the left transport lock disassembled: The bushing should be located in the opening on the sub-chassis arm on the right. item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Repair of a Broken SO ('Shut Off') Switch
item.description: This post continues the discussion about a malfunctioning “Shut Off” (SO) switch, which was missing a crucial plastic part, causing issues with the deck’s shutdown process. To address this, a 3D printed replacement part was designed and created. The “End Switch” (ES), still equipped with its plastic component, is pictured alongside the SO switch, highlighting the missing element. Creating a functional replacement part was challenging due to its small size and the limitations of the 3D printer.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5523): Installation of Beolover RIAA Preamp and 4002 Commander Remote Control
item.description: I recently refurbished a Beogram 4002 (5523), culminating in the installation of gold-plated RCA plugs. My customer opted to have my recently developed internal BeoloverRIAA preamplifier added, along with the 4002 Commander remote control system, which enables control of all functions via a paired Apple remote. This marks the first 4002 to feature both the Commander and the RIAA preamp – a true fusion of past and present! Pictures showcasing the installation process of the BeoloverRIAA board and the 4002 Commander are included.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Cabinet Repair and Guiding Washers Installation
item.description: While waiting for audio cables from Sounds Heavenly, I decided to fix up the wooden case of my Beogram 4002 (5513) turntable. Both corners were cracked, and the plastic washers that guide the sliding mechanism were gone. The first picture shows one of the damaged corners. [Image of a cracked turntable cabinet] Repairing the cracks was simple. Since the case is held together with metal bands, I glued the wood pieces and clamped them until the glue dried.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): End Groove Detection Not Working
item.description: Just when I thought I had finished refurbishing a Beogram 4002 (5513) turntable, a problem surfaced during playback. The tonearm wouldn’t return after playing a record, instead getting stuck in the end groove, repeating the sound of the run-out. Investigating further, I used an oscilloscope to examine the signal from the position sensor, which tells the control system the tonearm’s location. The signal was weak specifically in the end groove area, often indicating misalignment between the sensor’s IR diode and the light entry slit.

item.title: Beogram 4002 DC Platter Motor: Some Microsurgery on Disconnected Pickup Coils
item.description: I recently obtained a DC platter motor from a Beogram 4002 located in Norway. The motor required repair. The owner had already performed the ‘oil infusion’ procedure for the Oilite bearings. However, after reassembling and reinstalling the motor into the Beogram, the platter’s speed was excessively high and could not be adjusted. This image displays the motor, without the pulley, in the condition I received it: Uncontrollably high speed in a DC platter motor usually indicates a problem with one or both of the RPM feedback pickup coils within the motor, assuming the motor control circuit is functioning correctly.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5523): Installation of New Gold Plated RCA Plugs
item.description: The last step in restoring my Beogram 4002 (5523) was replacing the old and slightly corroded RCA plugs. item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Replacement of Degraded Transport Lock Bushings and Missing Cabinet Guiding Washers
item.description: The Beogram 4002 restoration involved addressing the common issue of fragile orange transport lock bushings and missing cabinet guiding washers. Many Beograms used plastic washers, which are prone to cracking and falling apart. This was evident in the restoration project, as some washers were missing entirely. To rectify this, five new 3D-printed washers were installed. For aesthetic purposes, using a black washer for the front-center position is recommended to avoid visibility through the gap between the aluminum panel and the plinth.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (Type 5513): A New Arrival from California - First Assessment
item.description: I recently received a Beogram 4002 turntable (model 5513) from a California customer. The turntable was shipped in a container provided by Beolover, ensuring a smooth transit process. This article details my initial assessment of the unit. Upon unboxing, the turntable appeared to be in fair cosmetic condition. However, there were noticeable fingerprints on the keypad and a few minor scratches on the aluminum panel. The plinth corners, on the other hand, were well-preserved.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5503): Exchanging all Electrolytic Capacitors
item.description: After finishing most of the mechanical work, it was time to start repairing the electronics on a Beogram 4002 (5503) turntable. Replacing all electrolytic capacitors is recommended, as their internal fluid often leaks or dries up. I use high-quality Japanese capacitors to ensure my repairs last as long as possible. Tantalum capacitors, in particular, must be replaced because they can fail dramatically if a short circuit occurs, potentially damaging the circuit board.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Restoration of DC Platter Motor, Main PCB and RPM Adjustment Panel
item.description: A Beogram 4002 turntable, experiencing RPM fluctuations, recently arrived from a customer for repair. The restoration process involved addressing issues with the DC platter motor, the main PCB, and the RPM adjustment panel. The platter motor was disassembled to lubricate the bearings. After immersing them in oil and applying a vacuum, the bearings were left undisturbed for two days to ensure proper saturation. Once the bubbling ceased, indicating full replenishment, the bearings were extracted and the motor was reassembled.

item.title: Beogram 4002 and 4004 DC Motor Restoration
item.description: I recently acquired two DC motors from Beogram 4002 and 4004 turntables located in Denmark. My typical first step is an oil infusion process to address RPM fluctuations, a common issue. The 4002 motor arrived in this condition: Disassembly revealed the following: The two small, donut-shaped brass bearings, visible on the black pad, were submerged in motor oil under a vacuum. Bubbles appeared immediately, indicating the oil infusion process was working.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5501): Repair of 'Knocking' AC Motor
item.description: I prefer to thoroughly test restored Beograms to ensure they’re free of intermittent issues. It’s not uncommon for new problems to appear with regular use. This was the case with a recently restored AC motor Beogram 4002 (5501). After playing a few records, I detected a faint knocking sound coming from inside the turntable. Upon removing the aluminum plates, I discovered the knocking synchronized with the AC motor’s rotation. Adjusting the motor tilt provided temporary noise reduction, but the knocking always returned, intensifying with each record played until it was noticeable during quieter tracks—an unacceptable issue for a turntable!

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): A New Arrival from Kentucky
item.description: A Beogram 4002 (Type 5513) turntable from Kentucky arrived safely thanks to its secure packaging. The turntable was in excellent cosmetic condition, with minimal scratching on the dust cover and un-cracked hinges. Upon removing the cover, the aluminum surfaces appeared nearly flawless, showing only minor signs of wear. The keypad was also well-preserved, exhibiting only slight deterioration on the START key and a few insignificant marks. The pristine condition of the keypad made it an ideal candidate for the Beolover Commander remote control system, which protects such keypads from further wear.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Test Drive with Herbie Hancock (Secrets)
item.description: I’m thrilled to share that I just got my hands on a nearly perfect copy of Herbie Hancock’s 1976 album “Secrets.” It’s in such great condition, it practically looks untouched! This album holds a special place in my heart, especially the track “People Music” with its captivating atmospheric interludes and those classic 70s analog synthesizer sounds, likely created on a “Maestro Universal Synthesizer System.” To celebrate, I decided to listen to the record on my newly restored Beogram 4002(5513) turntable, which is temporarily hooked up to my Beomaster 6000 4-Channel receiver for testing.

item.title: Beogram 4002 RIAA Preamplifier: A New Power Supply Design
item.description: This post follows up on my previous one about the RIAA preamplifier I’m building for a Beogram 4002 turntable. This preamp will allow the Beogram to connect directly to a modern amplifier’s AUX or TAPE input. While initially pleased with my prototype, I redesigned it for a cleaner layout and had it manufactured. The new boards arrived, and I assembled a preamplifier, thrilled with its appearance. After installing and testing it, however, I realized I hadn’t tested it thoroughly enough beforehand.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): A New Arrival from Texas
item.description: I recently received a Beogram 4002 (Type 5513) turntable from a Texas customer. It was shipped securely in a Beolover container. This post will provide an initial assessment of the turntable’s condition. A follow-up post will detail the restoration process to bring it back to like-new performance. item.title: Beogram 4000: Restoration of the Control Panel - LEDs and Gold Plating of Switch Terminals
item.description: Following the enhancement of the carriage position switches, the control panel restoration of a Beogram 4000 turntable commenced. The project involved a typical upgrade of incandescent bulbs to LED assemblies and gold plating of switch terminals for enhanced longevity and performance. item.title: Beogram 4002 (Type 5513): Full Upgrade with SyncDrive Platter Motor, Commander Remote Control and Internal RIAA Pre-Amplifier
item.description: A customer from Kentucky requested a full upgrade for their Beogram 4002 turntable, including three modifications: a SyncDrive motor for enhanced speed stability, a Commander remote control system for convenient operation and keypad protection, and a Beolover RIAA pre-amplifier for direct connection to modern audio equipment. All upgrades were installed without soldering. The SyncDrive replaced the original DC motor, connecting to existing mounting points and the main circuit board. The Beolover RIAA pre-amplifier replaced the output board, using compatible connectors for easy installation.

item.title: Beogram 4002 DC Motor Restoration: Repair of a Damaged Pickup Coil and Oil Infusion
item.description: A Beogram 4002 DC platter motor from Australia was sent in for repair. The owner reported the motor always ran at high speed, suggesting a broken RPM feedback coil. Without this feedback, the motor receives maximum power and spins as fast as possible. Disassembly revealed the motor’s brushes were improperly installed and a solder burn marked one terminal. The small pickup coils, responsible for sending an AC voltage proportional to motor RPM, were also examined.
